description: From a northern variant of Old English hwinsian (“to whine”), from Proto-West Germanic *hwinisōn (“to whine”), from Proto-West Germanic *hwīnan (“to whine”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱwey- (“to hiss, whistle, whisper”). Cognate with German winseln (“to whine, whimper”).

entries.meaning: (UK, Australia, New Zealand, Ireland) A cry.
examples: Her whinges grew even shriller and more annoying the longer we had to listen to them.

entries.meaning: (UK, Australia, New Zealand, Ireland) A peevish complaint.
examples: I know you don't like it, but your whinges won't solve the problem!

verbs.description: whinge (third-person singular simple present whinges, present participle whingeing or whinging, simple past and past participle whinged)

entries.meaning: (UK, Australia, New Zealand, Ireland) To whine; to complain, especially in an annoying or persistent manner.
examples: Argh! He has been whinging about it all night, even though he knows there's nothing we can do.
I know it won't help but sometimes it feels better to whinge about the things that annoy me.
